Physics-based virtual reality for task learning and intelligent disassembly planning
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Manufacturing and Construction
  • Published: 02 February 2010

Physics-based virtual reality for task learning and intelligent disassembly planning

  • Jacopo Aleotti1 &
  • Stefano Caselli1 

Virtual Reality volume 15, pages41–54(2011)Cite this article

  • 666 Accesses

  • 24 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Physics-based simulation is increasingly important in virtual manufacturing for product assembly and disassembly operations. This work explores potential benefits of physics-based modeling for automatic learning of assembly tasks and for intelligent disassembly planning in desktop virtual reality. The paper shows how realistic physical animation of manipulation tasks can be exploited for learning sequential constraints from user demonstrations. In particular, a method is proposed where information about physical interaction is used to discover task precedences and to reason about task similarities. A second contribution of the paper is the application of physics-based modeling to the problem of disassembly sequence planning. A novel approach is described to find all physically admissible subassemblies in which a set of rigid objects can be disassembled. Moreover, efficient strategies are presented aimed at reducing the computational time required for automatic disassembly planning. The proposed strategies take into account precedence relations arising from user assembly demonstrations as well as geometrical clustering. A motion planning technique has also been developed to generate non-destructive disassembly paths in a query-based approach. Experiments have been performed in an interactive virtual environment including a dataglove and motion tracker that allows realistic object manipulation and grasping.

Introduction

Virtual manufacturing refers to the application of computer graphics and simulation to model real world manufacturing processes. Assembly and disassembly operations are key components in many manufacturing processes and should also be supported in a virtual manufacturing system. As a matter of fact, interactive manufacturing applications demand increasingly realistic environments. Thus, the use of advanced physics-based animation, which describes the motion of objects with Newtonian laws, has become an essential feature for increasing the degree of realism and believability in such context. This work presents a desktop virtual reality system for interactive assembly operations and automatic product disassembly.

Virtual reality technologies provide advanced methods of realtime user interaction. Moreover, realistic behavior of animated bodies can enhance the feeling of immersion and improve performance of the user.

This paper explores the idea of applying physics-based animation for automatic learning of sequential task constraints programmed in a desktop virtual environment. The approach exploits information about physical interaction between simulated bodies to discover task precedences across multiple demonstrations and to reason about task similarities at the goal level. The proposed method is focused on the recognition of discrete actions and is founded on the Programming by Demonstration paradigm (Ikeuchi and Suehiro 1994; Ogata and Takahashi 1994; Zöllner et al. 2005; Aleotti and Caselli 2007). A task precedence graph is learned from multiple demonstrations performed by a human teacher in the virtual environment. The system supports virtual grasping and uses a dataglove and a motion tracker for tracking human hand motion and driving a simulated anthropomorphic hand. As a simple example, consider the task of dragging an object on a table with friction to let it fall on the ground. The same task can be achieved in many different ways. For example, the object can be pulled with a virtual hand or pushed with a grasped tool. Regardless of the way in which the object is dragged the key feature of the task is the application of an adequate force toward the border of the table. In this work, we show that reasoning at the physical level allows the system to learn such core concepts. To achieve comparable effects in simplified virtual environments, which do not rely on physical simulation, artificial scripted routines must be pre-programmed.

As a further contribution, a computational method for planning disassembly tasks is proposed which relies on physics-based animation. The method differs from the large amount of previous works on disassembly planning as discussed in Sect. 2. In particular, an effective approach is described for automatic evaluation of subassembly stability and disassembly planning. Systematic stability evaluation is achieved by means of a physics simulation engine. The problem can be stated as follows. First, find all the physically stable subassemblies in which a collection of rigid bodies can be disassembled. Second, identify feasible disassembly motions for all objects by applying a single-query motion planning algorithm. The adopted solution ensures realistic non-destructive disassembly operations, meaning that the objects are disassembled by looking only at continuous paths. Stability of object configurations is computed taking into account both gravity and friction. It is assumed that only pure contact forces act on the bodies in the physics-based environment. External interconnections such as forces due to connectors like glue, screws or bolts are not considered.

In order to reduce the computational time required to compute all the admissible subassemblies of a given set of objects, efficient strategies are introduced for identifying as many stable configurations as possible without the need of a physical simulation. One of the optimizations takes advantage of precedence relations arising from user assembly demonstrations. Indeed, multiple demonstrations of the same assembly task are collected and redundancy is exploited to detect a reduced subset of candidate precedence relations. A precedence relation between the two objects means that the first object must be assembled before the second one.

Another proposed optimization consists of a spatial clustering algorithm that groups geometrically adjacent objects, thus allowing stability evaluation on sets of lower dimensions and also enabling parallel processing. The proposal of disassembly optimizations as well as the non-destructive disassembly planner constitute novel contributions extending previous work (Aleotti and Caselli 2009). Experiments of automatic disassembly planning have been performed in the same interactive virtual environment that is also exploited for task demonstration.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews the state of the art concerning task precedence learning, assembly stability evaluation and disassembly planning. Section 3 describes the software components and the interaction devices of the virtual reality system, while Sect. 4 describes the proposed physics-based method for learning task constraints and reports experiments. Section 5 illustrates the method for efficient stability evaluation. Section 6 focuses on the non-destructive disassembly planner. The paper closes in Sect. 7 summarizing the work.

State of the art

Several works focused on the combination of physics-based modeling and object manipulation with user feedback (Bergamasco et al. 1994; Borst and Indugula 2005; Hirota and Hirose 2003; Huagen et al. 2004; Zaeh et al. 2004; Jayaram et al. 1999). However, all these papers are strictly focused on achieving realistic behavior of interactive simulation. Applications of physics-based modeling to the problem of task learning and disassembly sequence planning have never been reported. In particular, Borst and Indugula (2005) addressed the issue of hand animation by coupling tracked hand configuration to a simulation-controlled hand using a system of linear and torsional spring-dampers. Jayaram et al. (1999) developed the VADE system for assembly design, which supports both constrained motion simulation and dynamic simulation for assembly assistance. Several authors have investigated the potential of physics-based VR environments for improving user’s performance in assembly and manipulation tasks. Lim et al. (2007) evaluated the benefits of haptic feedback and stereovision in a peg-in-hole task. Howard and Vance (2007) presented an affordable desktop VR environment for assembly tasks. Garbaya and Zaldivar-Colado (2007) addressed the problem of part-to-part contacts during the mating phase of assembly tasks. The study showed that when force feedback includes a contribution of forces generated by the contact between parts user performance is improved compared with the situation where haptic sensation reproduces only the forces representing the contact between the virtual hand and the grasped object. Sung et al. (2009) presented two computer-aided tools for virtual assembly and analyzed time savings that could be obtained as opposed to manual specification of the assembly plan.

Analysis of assembly precedence graphs from a theoretical point of view has been considered in various works. Chen and Henrioud (1994) presented a method for systematic generation of all feasible assembly precedence graphs for mechanical products. Ramos et al. (1997) analyzed the complexity of precedence graphs. The closest work to ours is by Zöllner et al. (2005) and Pardowitz et al. (2005) where the authors described a system for learning household tasks by demonstration. The system learns sequential constraints based on multiple demonstrations and generates the corresponding precedence graph. Two hypotheses are assumed. First, manipulation operations must belong to a closed set of actions. Two different operations that have the same effects cannot be added to the precedence graph. Secondly, each demonstration must solve the same task. Departing from Zöllner et al. (2005) and Pardowitz et al. (2005), the present work shows that reasoning at the physical level allows relaxation of the first hypothesis, i.e., manipulation operations are no longer constrained to belong to a pre-defined set of actions. Indeed, actions that determine the same effects on the environment can be considered as alternatives to solve a task and therefore can be included in the same precedence graph. The problem of automatic task learning has been considered in many works in the robotics domain, as for example, in the seminal works of Ikeuchi and Suehiro (1994) and Ogata and Takahashi (1994). An important aspect that has also been investigated with different approaches is the ability to cope with new situations and to learn tasks that are not known in advance. Ogawara et al. (2003) introduced a method for estimating essential interactions from multiple demonstrations. The work proposed in this paper goes in a similar direction as it provides a method that is able to generalize demonstrated tasks and discover task similarities by reasoning about physical interactions.

Hereafter, related works concerning assembly stability evaluation and disassembly planning are reviewed. De Mello and Sanderson (1990) introduced the AND/OR graph representation for assembly plans. Such representation constitutes the basis for several planning systems. Mattikalli et al. (1990) proposed a geometric methodology to automatically determine the disassembly sequence using combinations of translational and rotational motions. Waarts et al. (1992) presented an automatic sequence planner that takes into account feasibility and accessibility of operations but not stability under gravity. Automatic generation of mechanical assembly sequences from liaison graphs has been considered by many authors (Lee 1994; Dong et al. 2006). Lee and Yi (1993) described an efficient method for reducing the search space by pruning unstable subassemblies. Ong and Wong (1999) introduced a methodology for automatically extracting subassemblies which group components together based on the criteria of connectivity and interference relationships. Another efficient approach was proposed by Loomis and Balkcom (2006) based on computational reuse of rigid-body dynamics but limited to planar 2D environments.

A number of authors investigated theoretical approaches for finding all potential stable orientations of assemblies within a uniform gravity field and Coulomb friction (Mattikalli et al. 1996; Mosemann et al. 1997). Sundaram et al. (2001) exploited conventional motion planning strategies for automatic disassembly. Cortes et al. (2008) described a Manhattan-like motion planner based on Rapidly exploring Random Tree (M-RRT) suitable for disassembly of objects with articulated parts. Aguinaga et al. (2008) proposed the targetless RRT (T-RRT) algorithm which has been adopted as a component of our physics-based disassembly planning system (Sect. 6). In Halperin et al. (1998), a general framework for disassembly planning is presented, which is based on the concept of motion space. Torres et al. (2003) developed a disassembly sequence planner that exploits information encoded as precedence relations introduced by an operator who knows the product. Gadh et al. (1998) proposed a virtual disassembly tool for product dismantling that involves a cost metric. The importance of taking into account stability in disassembly planning was pointed out by Lee and Yi (1993) that illustrated different criteria for reducing the search space by pruning unstable subassemblies. In Lee and Wang (1993), an assembly planning system has been designed that includes physical reasoning about interconnection forces. The approach presented in this paper differs from all the previously cited papers since it includes systematic stability evaluation by means of a physics engine. Moreover, it allows disassembly planning from user-built structures in virtual reality.

System overview

Figure 1 shows the desktop VR environment developed in this work and the devices involved. The graphical output of the virtual environment is managed by a scene graph engine (developed upon OpenGL) while physics animation is based on the Open Dynamics Engine (http://www.ode.org). A collision detection algorithm has been integrated (OPCODE, Optimized Collision Detection). Colliding bodies are simulated by creating hard contact constraints between them. Discrete rigid bodies can be simulated as well as articulated structures connected by joints. The constraint equation for a joint has the form Ju = b, where u is the velocity vector comprising all the linear and angular velocities of each object, J is the Jacobian matrix that describes the constraints with one row for each degree of freedom removed from the system by the joint and b is a term used for error correction. Complex shapes described by triangle meshes are supported. The virtual environment comprises a full articulated anthropomorphic model of the human hand. Motion of the user’s hand is coupled to the 3D model of the human hand which has 22 degrees of freedom. Full hand pose estimation is achieved through a dataglove and motion tracker. The adopted dataglove is a CyberTouch (by Immersion Corporation, Inc.), while the tracking device is a FasTrak (by Polhemus, Inc.).

A virtual grasping algorithm has also been developed. The algorithm evaluates the stability of a grasped object according to a standard grasp quality metric based on the grasp wrench space and enables manipulation tasks. Once a grasp is recognized as stable the virtual object is linked to the virtual hand and it can be carried in the simulated environment. Currently, the system does not allow full dextrous manipulation of grasped objects with fingertips. Vibratory feedback is generated for signaling contacts to the user. The system supports ballistic motion of objects under the effect of gravity and models grasped bodies with a spring-damper scheme. Figure 2 shows three examples of tasks performed in the physics-based virtual environment. The examples include manipulation of a non-convex shape, a constrained tool handling task, and throwing of a spherical object against a wall of blocks.

Physics-based learning of task constraints

In this section, after recalling the definition of task precedence graph two learning experiments of task constraints are presented that take into account information about physical interaction among simulated bodies. A task precedence graph (TPG) is a directed, acyclic graph G = {V, E}, where V is the finite set of feasible elementary actions \(V=\{t_1,t_2,\ldots,t_n\}\) and E ⊂ V × V is a set of arcs. Each element (t a , t b ) of E is a precedence relation between the two actions meaning that t a must be completed before the execution of action t b can start. A single-user demonstration \(D_{i}=\{t_{i_{1}},t_{i_{2}},\ldots ,t_{i_{n}}\}\) with \(t_{i_{j}}\in V\) is compliant with a precedence graph G = {V, E} if every pair \((t_{i_{h}},t_{i_{l}})\) with h < l satisfies the task constraints defined by E. A TPG can be learned from a sequence of m demonstrations of the same task. The learning process is incremental. After the first demonstration \(D_{1}=\{t_{1_{1}},t_{1_{2}},\ldots ,t_{1_{n}}\}\) has been performed, the set of constraints \(E_{1}=E^{D_{1}}=\{(t_{1_{i}},t_{1_{j}})|i<j\}\) is initialized with all the precedence relations contained in D 1. Note that these might be either actual precedence constraints or choices of the specific demonstration. For each additional demonstration D k of the same task, the TPG is updated by refining the set of valid precedence relations \((E_{k+1}=E_{k} \cap E^{D_{k+1}}).\) Namely, the updated TPG is given by the intersection of the past knowledge about the task with the precedence relations introduced by the latest demonstration. Therefore, the cardinality of the set of precedence relations may only decrease as multiple demonstrations are provided, since new demonstrations have the effect of removing previous constraints by showing alternative possible solutions for the task. By definition, each action has a number of pre- and post-conditions that describe the state of the environment at the beginning and at the end of each action.

As anticipated in Sect. 2, Zöllner et al. (2005) and Pardowitz et al. (2005) proposed a system for sequential task learning, which is based on two hypotheses. First, the learning system cannot handle demonstrations where different actions have the same post-conditions. Secondly, two demonstrations are not detected as similar if they perform different tasks. In this work, the first hypothesis is relaxed by introducing an approach that is able to handle demonstrations containing different actions that have the same physical effects on the environment. Therefore, elementary actions are not constrained to belong to a pre-defined set of actions. By reasoning at the physical level, identical post-conditions can be identified and hence the equivalence of different actions is established.

Experiments

Two learning experiments of manipulation tasks are illustrated. The first experiment involves pick and place operations and button switching actions. Figure 3 shows relevant task features by reporting a sequence of images taken from the first user demonstration. Table 1 summarizes the set of actions that were recognized in the experiment after three demonstrations of the same task. There are three pick and place operations (A, C, D) and two actions that trigger a button (B 1, B 2). The environment comprises two horizontal platforms (colored in green and blue) located on the top of the scene that are initially joined together by a hinge joint. The joint can be broken by pushing the red button on the left side of the scene. Hence, the two platforms act as a trapdoor. Figure 4 shows the details of the actions performed in the three demonstrations as well as the task precedence graph learned incrementally. Table 2 reports the details of the learning process. In particular, for each demonstration D k , the corresponding set of constraints \(E^{D_{k}}\) is reported as well as the refined set E k of all valid precedence relations. The TPG shown in Fig. 4 has been generated from the resulting set E 3 of learned precedence relations.

In the first demonstration, the user first grasps the yellow dish and places it on the ground under the platforms (action D). Then, he puts the glass on the dish (action C) and the sphere on top of the two platforms (action A). Finally, the user pushes the button with the virtual hand (action B 1) which causes the trapdoor to open and the sphere to fall into the underlying glass (if properly aligned). Contact force between the finger and the button is computed as proportional to the penetration depth of the bodies. In the second demonstration, the user performs the same task by permutating the order of the first three actions (D, A, C), and then he activates the button by putting a box on top of it. The weight of the box causes the button to trigger the opening of the trapdoor. The action is labeled as B 2. The learning system discovers that action B 1 and B 2 have the same physical post-conditions since they both switch the button. Hence, the two actions are considered as similar and labeled as B. Eventually, the resulting TPG after the second demonstration shows a refined set of precedence relations between actions A, C, D and, more importantly, the presence of the new labeled action B in place of B 1 and B 2. After the third demonstration, the TPG is further refined as the system learns that the action of placing the sphere on the platform is independent of the placement of the dish and glass.

The second experiment (Fig. 5) shows a different environment with daily life objects being manipulated. Table 3 summarizes the set of actions that were recognized in the experiment, again, after three demonstrations of the task. Action A 1 is the pick and place of a glass with a sphere inside the opened red container. Action A 2 is the pick and place of the glass, without any object inside, in the opened container. Action B is the insertion of the sphere in the glass. Action C is the pick and place in the opened container of a yellow box. Lastly, action D is the opening of the container by the removal of its cover. The cover is grasped by the virtual hand and then is laid down on the ground. Figure 5 shows a sequence of images of the first demonstration, while Fig. 6 shows the actions performed in each demonstration and the learned TPG. Table 4 reports the details of the learning process.

In the first demonstration, the user first opens the container (action D), then he puts the sphere in the glass (action B). After that, the user grasps the glass and moves it inside the opened container (action A 1) and then it moves the yellow box inside the container as well (action C). In the second demonstration, the user provides an alternative method to solve the same task. After opening the container, the glass is moved inside alone (action A 2), then the box is picked and placed in the container (action C) and finally the sphere is inserted in the glass (action B). Since the transportation of the ball inside the glass is handled transparently by the physics engine the system learns that actions A 1 and A 2 can be considered as the same task of picking the glass and carrying it inside the container regardless of the presence of an object inside the glass. The task is labeled as A. After the last demonstration, the final TPG is generated showing the independence of action B from all the other actions and that action D has precedence over A and C.

The proposed examples show that physics-based animation enables the discovery of equivalence between states in a virtual environment. By means of simple demonstrations in VR an autonomous system can learn the set of precedence relations that constitute a manufacturing task.

Efficient stability evaluation for disassembly planning

Assemblies are collections of objects. Disassembly planning is the problem of finding appropriate motions that are applied to the individual parts of an assembly to separate the initial agglomerate. A statically stable assembly configuration is a composition of objects that does not collapse under the effect of gravity forces and static friction. A disassembly motion of an object is feasible if the object can reach an infinite distance from its initial location without colliding with the remaining bodies and if the resulting subassembly configuration (obtained by removing the object) is still stable. A disassembly sequence is a succession of feasible motions that are applied to the objects one by one starting from an initial configuration that includes all the objects in the environment. Disassembly planning has important applications in industrial manufacturing for recycling and for cost reduction in product dismantling. Assembly and disassembly problems are interrelated since assembly plans can be derived from disassembly sequences. Disassembly planning is a typical combinatorial problem where the total number of possible disassembly sequences is given by the factorial n! of the number of objects in the initial configuration. Therefore, even a rather small environment with ten objects has a potential of more than three millions of possible disassembly sequences. Moreover, computation of the stability of a given configuration is NP-hard.

This section describes the proposed method for finding all the physically stable subassemblies (static analysis) of a collection of objects and its optimization. The algorithm also computes all the possible destructive disassembly sequences. The key concept of the method is a form of experiential learning where actions are discovered by means of physical simulation. A second phase, discussed in Sect. 6, performs non-destructive disassembly planning in a query-based approach for selected sequences of stable disassembly plans. Stable subassemblies are organized into a disassembly graph. A disassembly graph of a set of n objects P = {p 1, ..., p n } is defined as a directed, acyclic graph G = {X, C}, where X is the set of nodes corresponding to the stable subassembly configurations (partitions of P), while C represents the set of arcs. Each arc is an oriented edge that connects two configurations X i and X j , where the stable configuration X j can be obtained from X i by removing one object. Configuration X j is called a child node of X i . The initial state \(X_{0}=\{p_{1},\ldots,p_{n}\}\) comprises all the objects in the environment. The terminal nodes are all the stable configurations that comprise only one object. A stable destructive disassembly sequence is given by any path of nodes from the root to the terminal nodes of the graph. Figure 7 shows the interactive virtual environment with one example of stable configuration as well as one unstable collapsing configuration.

Algorithm 1 reports the pseudo-code for generating the disassembly subgraph of a generic node configuration, while Algorithm 2 reports the procedure used for testing the stability of a node. The disassembly phase starts by invoking Algorithm 1 on the root node of the graph (compute_disassembly_graph(X 0)), which contains all the objects in the environment. The disassembly graph is generated iteratively by computing the stability of each configuration. Each child node is generated by removing an object from the parent configuration. Unstable configurations are removed from the graph, and their children nodes are pruned. Algorithm 2 shows that in order to evaluate the stability of a configuration the system performs a physics-based simulation of the subassembly for a pre-defined time and computes, at each step, the linear and angular velocities of all the bodies in the environment. If both velocities do not exceed pre-defined small thresholds within the simulation period, the configuration is considered stable. If the velocity limits are exceeded then the simulation is stopped and the configuration is considered as unstable. Optimizations A and B, mentioned in Algorithm 2, are described later in Sect. 5.1. To improve the performance of the disassembly algorithm, the graphical output is disabled in this phase.

Algorithm 1 Computation of disassembly subgraph of a node configuration
1: procedure compute_disassembly_graph(X i )
2: Initialize graph with node X i
3: for all Nodes in the graph do
4:   if (!node_is_stable) then
5:    node_is_stable=evaluate_node_stability(current_node)
6:   end if
7:   if (node_is_stable) then
8:    Environment_cluster()
9:    if clusters_found > 1 then
10:     for all clusters do
11:      compute_disassembly_graph(cluster)
12:     end for
13:     Merge clusters and update stability of nodes
14:    else
15:     Add children nodes to the graph
16:    end if
17:   else
18:    remove current_node from the graph
19:   end if
20: end for
Algorithm 2 Evaluation of node stability
1: procedure evaluate_node_stability(current_node)
2: node_is_stable \(\Leftarrow true\)
3: if Optimization rules (A,B) fail then
4:   for iteration = 0 to MAX_ITERATION do
5:    for all objects in current_node do
6:     Compute linear and angular velocity
7:     if (linear_velocity≥LinVel_threshold)
     or (angular_velocity≥AngVel_threshold) then
8:      node_is_stable \(\Leftarrow false\)
9:      return node_is_stable
10:     end if
11:    end for
12:    Advance step of simulation
13:   end for
14: end if
15: return node_is_stable

Optimization of disassembly planning

The bottleneck of the disassembly algorithm is clearly the physics-based disassembly routine. Without any optimization, the computational time required to compute all possible disassembly sequences may quickly become excessive, due to the combinatorial nature of the problem. One might be tempted to reduce the computational time required to evaluate the stability of a configuration by simply reducing the time period or the velocity thresholds. However, such constants cannot be arbitrarily reduced, as this would lead to the generation of false-positive stable configurations. Therefore, to speed-up the disassembly phase, efficient strategies are introduced that automatically assess the stability of a configuration. The idea is to perform the physics-based simulation for as few configurations as possible. The proposed optimization methods take into account multiple user demonstrations of assembly sequences, precedence relations between assembled objects, and geometrical object clustering. The user can provide assembly demonstrations by performing grasping and placing operations in the physics-based virtual environment. The optimization strategies are discussed in the following.

  • Optimization A is a trivial use of prior knowledge about stable configurations. Configurations that are known to be stable in advance are subassemblies extracted from user demonstrations. Each complete user demonstration of an assembly configuration X i that comprises n objects provides a prior knowledge of n subassembly configurations that are stable. In case optimization A is enabled, Algorithm 2 avoids the physics-based test if the current configuration belongs to the set of the configurations that are known to be stable.

  • Optimization B exploits precedence relations between objects. There exists a precedence relation between two objects (o a , o b ) if o a (pre-condition) must be assembled before o b (post-condition). Each complete user demonstration of an assembly configuration X i that comprises n ≥ 2 objects provides a total of \(\sum_{k=1}^{n}(k-1)=\frac{n(n-1)}{2}\) precedence relations. The set R of all precedence relations is reduced as multiple demonstrations are provided due to generalization of task constraints. Let X j be a configuration obtained from X i by removing object o r . If o r is not a pre-condition in any precedence relation involving other objects contained in X i then X j is automatically stable. Formally, if \({\forall}o_{i} \in X_{i}\,\setminus\,\{o_{r}\}\,\nexists\, (o_{r},o_{i})\,\in\,R\) then X j is stable. It is trivial to show that optimization B implies optimization A, meaning that all stable configurations that can be identified by applying optimization A can also be found by optimization B. However, optimization A is slightly faster.

  • Optimization C is based on an object clustering approach. An algorithm has been developed that identifies clusters of adjacent objects by means of collision detection [another approach for object clustering is proposed in Sappa and Garcia (2004)]. If a configuration may be split into at least two clusters then clusters are disassembled separately in sequential order. A merging procedure is then applied that automatically generates all the stable configurations from the partial subtrees without the need of a physics simulation.

  • Optimization D extends optimization C by performing parallel multi-threaded computation of the identified clusters on a multi-core CPU. Recursive clustering has been limited by empirical assumptions on the number of objects in the clusters to avoid excessive overhead in handling multiple concurrent threads.

Experiments

This section describes experiments that have been performed to validate the performance of the proposed optimization strategies for stability evaluation. Four experiments are presented that span different environmental conditions. Figure 8 shows the final assembly configuration of each example where objects are labeled with progressive integer numbers. These environments have been assembled interactively by the user. In addition to the individual optimizations, two combined optimizations have been experimented, A + B which stands for a combined approach exploiting both prior knowledge about stable subassemblies and precedence-based optimization, and A + B + D that adds clustering and parallel processing. Table 5 summarizes the experimental results. The computational time required to compute all the possible disassembly sequences (including those sequences that require destructive operations) is reported for all optimizations. The number of physics-based disassembly attempts and the number of stable configurations that have been completely simulated is also included for each optimization. Finally, Table 5 reports for each experiment, the speedup obtained by optimization A + B + D, the total number of stable configurations, the total number of disassembly sequences and the list of the provided assembly demonstrations (each demonstration is represented as a set where objects appear in the order in which they are assembled by the user). Reported times do not include time spent by the user during the demonstration phase. However, while it can be assumed that task demonstration time increases linearly with the number of demonstrations, the reduction of computational time (with optimization enabled) scales more than linearly as more demonstrations are provided by the user (as confirmed by the reported experiments). Experiments have been run on an Intel Core 2 quad CPU (@2.66 GHz, 4 Gb RAM).

Experiment 1 is a complex environment comprising 11 objects. Three clusters of adjacent objects can be immediately identified at the beginning of the disassembly process ({1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, {8, 9, 10, 11}, {7}). Four assembly demonstrations are provided by the user. A first observation, which holds for all the experiments, is that the computational time of each trial is essentially determined by the total number of stable configurations that have been completely simulated. Optimization B performs significantly better than optimization A. Optimization A + B does not provide any significant improvement compared to B alone thus confirming that optimization B is more general than A. Moreover, the clustering approach, in this experiment, outperforms both optimizations A and B, as only 17 configurations were required to be tested. Optimization A + B + D provided the best result with a total time of 14.11 s and only four fully simulated configurations. Another general observation is that parallel computation (D) provides only a limited improvement over the sequential clustering approach (C) where clusters are disassembled with a single thread. This behavior is due to the relative small size of the clusters that are identified in the proposed examples. In principle, environments with larger clusters would benefit from a parallel approach but they cannot be easily tested since the total number of possible disassembly sequences would become intractable.

Experiment 2 comprises 10 objects. Four assembly demonstrations are provided by the user. The initial configuration is a single agglomerate of objects. However, if the clustering optimization is enabled after removal of object 1 (glass) and object 2 the algorithm is able to identify two separate clusters each one made of four objects ({3, 4, 5, 6}, {7, 8, 9, 10}). Figure 9 shows the disassembly trees of the two clusters and the resulting merged subgraph, which is a partial subtree as well since it does not include objects 1 and 2. The merged tree is automatically generated and therefore all its nodes do not have to be physically simulated. The large size of the merged tree compared to the size of its parent subgraphs highlights the high efficiency of the clustering optimization in finding stable configurations. It is also interesting to note that in this experiment optimization B alone provides even better results than C.

The last two experiments illustrate particular environment configurations. Experiment 3 comprises 9 isolated objects lying on the ground. Four assembly demonstrations are initially provided by the user. Since all the objects are stable and they are not colliding with each other, there are 9 single-body clusters and the total number of possible disassembly sequences is given by all the possible permutations of the initial configuration (9! = 362880). It turns out that the clustering optimization C outperforms both A and B. Parallel processing does not improve efficiency as all the clusters contain only one object. Optimization B alone is anyhow more than three times faster than the result obtained without any optimization. It is also worthwhile mentioning that if a fifth demonstration is added by the user (given by the following ordered assembly sequence {8, 1, 4, 9, 2, 7, 6, 5, 3}) then the computational time of optimization B drops to 37.7 s, meaning that providing more demonstrations and hence reducing the number of precedence constraints greatly helps the optimization process. However, it must be pointed out that providing a large number of demonstrations can be demanding and time consuming for the user, whereas optimization C is performed automatically by the system without the need for user involvement.

Experiment 4 comprises 10 objects that are organized into a single cluttered cluster. The environment configuration determines a large number of physical constraints. Therefore, the total number of disassembly sequences as well as the disassembly time are quite low. All 16 disassembly sequences are reported in Table 6. An important observation is that the presence of a single cluster for each possible subassembly state determines that the clustering optimization is ineffective whereas optimizations A and B provide a speedup of more than two.

A general conclusion that can be deduced from the previous examples is that optimizations B and C are somehow complementary since they provide positive effects in different environment conditions. In particular, optimization C is effective for environments where separate clusters can emerge in the disassembly phase, while optimization B is effective for constrained environments given a sufficient number of user demonstrations. The combined use of the two optimizations leads to the best performance.

Discussion

The proposed method can find suitable applications in real industrial environments for solving automatic assembly decomposition problems and recycling. The work goes in the direction of providing novel insights toward the development of intelligent systems for simulating assembly operations. An important issue of discussion is that a straightforward application of the proposed method in complex environments would certainly lead to an explosion of the computational time due to the high number of possible disassembly sequences. In such realistic situations, it would make sense to set aside a complete algorithm, which looks for all the possible disassembly sequences, and investigate alternative strategies returning a reduced set of solutions of the disassembly problem, from a partial exploration of the state space of the subassembly configurations.

Non-destructive disassembly planning

A non-destructive disassembly planner has been developed to generate physically plausible disassembly motions. A disassembly motion of an object is non-destructive if the object can reach an infinite distance from its initial location without colliding with the remaining bodies. The input of the planner is one of the disassembly sequences identified by applying the algorithm described in Sect. 5. The planner returns the computed disassembly motions if the selected sequence of objects can be successfully disassembled in a non-destructive manner, otherwise the planner returns that a non-destructive disassembly path cannot be found. The adopted motion planner is derived from the method proposed in Aguinaga et al. (2008). At first, the motion planner tries to disassemble an object by applying forces along pre-computed removal directions. Removal directions are vectors sampled on the unit upward hemisphere that do not point toward bodies that are initially in contact with the object to be disassembled. Therefore, each disassembly attempt is a physics-based simulation that moves an object along a straight line. A disassembly attempt is successful if it is able to guide the object beyond a distance threshold without any collision to the other bodies in the environment. If all the straight-line disassembly attempts fail, then a motion planner based on Rapidly exploring Random Tree is invoked in order to detect feasible disassembly paths that require more complex motions. The approach is called targetless RRT (T-RRT) (Aguinaga et al. 2008) since it does not require to reach a specific goal configuration. A difference from the original algorithm (Aguinaga et al. 2008) is that in the proposed implementation feasible disassembly paths are simulated in the physics-based environment by applying forces and torques to the object. The resulting disassembly solution is more realistic than a purely kinematic one, since the computed part motions take into account also physics constraints.

An example of a non-destructive disassembly plan is presented in Fig. 10. The environment consists of a caged bunny, which is the first object to be disassembled. The bunny cannot be disassembled using simple removal directions, but the T-RRT planner is able to find a feasible path. The top left image also shows the generated random tree. The remaining objects can be disassembled using the straight-line-removal approach.

Conclusions

In this paper, the concept of physics-based modeling in virtual reality has been applied to the problem of learning task precedence graphs and automatic disassembly planning. A method for automatic learning of task constraints arising from manufacturing tasks demonstrated by a user has been proposed. The approach improves previous results, where information about physics interaction was not considered and relaxes the hypothesis that elementary actions belong to a closed set. It has been shown that reasoning at the physical level allows the learning system to discover task similarities across multiple demonstrations. A second contribution of this work is the proposal of a novel approach for efficient disassembly planning of rigid bodies. The method allows computation of all the physically stable subassembly configurations and all the possible destructive disassembly sequences of a set of objects. Optimizations based on precedence relations and geometrical clustering have been proposed. A non-destructive algorithm for computing feasible disassembly paths has also been successfully integrated.
